document: Lecture 5 covered brute‑force algorithms for problems such as string matching, polynomial evaluation, closest‑pair, travelling salesman problem, knapsack, and assignment problem.

questions.question: The brute‑force string matching algorithm compares each character of the pattern to the text until a mismatch is detected.
Brute‑force polynomial evaluation can be improved using Horner’s rule, reducing multiplications from O(n²) to O(n).
The closest‑pair problem has a brute‑force solution that runs in Θ(n log n) time.
The travelling salesman problem brute‑force algorithm examines all possible tours, taking factorial time.
The knapsack problem can be solved by exhaustive search with O(2ⁿ) complexity.
The assignment problem brute‑force method requires generating all n! permutations to find the minimum cost assignment.
In the closest‑pair brute‑force algorithm you need only compute distances between each pair of points once.
The Hungarian method runs in O(n³) time for the assignment problem.
Exhaustive search is efficient on large instances with many variables.
Brute‑force string matching algorithm can find a pattern in Θ(mn) comparisons in the worst case.
Polynomial evaluation using Horner’s rule still requires O(n²) multiplications.
The closest‑pair problem can be made faster by divide‑and‑conquer to run in Θ(n²).
Knapsack exhaustive search examines all 2ⁿ subsets of items.
Assignment brute force can be represented using a binary vector for each assignment.
Brute‑force algorithms often produce reasonable solutions for some problems such as sorting and searching.
The brute‑force polynomial evaluation algorithm described uses nested loops to compute powers of x.
Travelling salesman problem brute force algorithm runs in Θ((n–1)!) time).
In the assignment problem, each person can be assigned to only one job but jobs can have multiple persons.
Brute‑force algorithms are rarely constructive as other design techniques.
Exhaustive search is also known as backtracking.
